import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline
exam = pd.read_csv('../input/students-performance-in-exams/StudentsPerformance.csv')
exam.head()
source.9e867f64: sns.barplot(x = "race/ethnicity", y = "math score", data = exam, hue = 'gender')
source.6440d5f8: sns.barplot(x = "race/ethnicity", y = "reading score", data = exam, hue = 'gender')
source.2cdf32fc: sns.barplot(x = "race/ethnicity", y = "writing score", data = exam, hue = 'gender')
source.9b387bda:
fig,ax = plt.subplots(2,2,figsize=(15,12))

#Math and reading scores
ax[0,0].scatter(x='math score',y='reading score',data=exam[exam['gender']=='male'],alpha=0.5,label='male')
ax[0,0].scatter(x='math score',y='reading score',data=exam[exam['gender']=='female'],alpha=0.5,label='female')
ax[0,0].set_xlabel('Math Scores')
ax[0,0].set_ylabel('Reading Scores')
ax[0,0].set_title('Math and reading score')
ax[0,0].legend()

# Mathematics and Writing Scores
ax[0,1].scatter(x='math score',y='writing score',data=exam[exam['gender']=='male'],alpha=0.5,label='male')
ax[0,1].scatter(x='math score',y='writing score',data=exam[exam['gender']=='female'],alpha=0.5,label='female')
ax[0,1].set_xlabel('Math Scores')
ax[0,1].set_ylabel('Writing Scores')
ax[0,1].set_title('Math and writing score')
ax[0,1].legend()
# Reading and writing Scores
ax[1,0].scatter(x='writing score',y='reading score',data=exam[exam['gender']=='male'],alpha=0.5,label='male')
ax[1,0].scatter(x='writing score',y='reading score',data=exam[exam['gender']=='female'],alpha=0.5,label='female')
ax[1,0].set_xlabel('Reading Score')
ax[1,0].set_ylabel('Writing Score')
ax[1,0].set_title('Reading and writing score')
ax[1,0].legend()
ax[1,1].set_visible(False)

from sklearn import metrics
print('MAE:', metrics.mean_absolute_error(y_test, pred))

source.3671cfd8: 1000 rows and 8 columns, since we have to predict performanace, we will use regression models after doing EDA
source.587cb548: Students having standard lunch score more than those with free/reduced lunch. this also seems pretty significant, more so than test prep. strange. now we will train our regression models.
source.d79ac1a1: in general, students having done prep, score significantly more marks. there is a minimum of 5-7 marks difference and a maximum of 10+. so this a pretty significant feature, we will not drop it.
source.7059c5b3: most parent have some college experience and almost as many have an associate degree. parents having masters degreee are rare. Lets see this feature's influence on student's performance.
source.79c287ee: clearly,there is large corr b/w read and write score
source.aa0b0a60: Clearly, children of parent with master's degree score better overall. especially noticeable in math scores. another observation is that children of parents having "some highschool" get more marks than children of parents having "high school". this feature is more significant than race\ethnicity, hence if need be, it will eb removed AFTER that.
source.59884235: first we will observe the distribution of ethnicity in the students
source.43ffecbb:
Except in math, females score more marks than males. Also in maths, group E has a noticeable edge over others. However, in the other subjects, the difference is less noticeable but group D and group E always remain above the cut. overall, group E stduents have higher scores than others. However the overall performance difference between these groups isn’t that sighnificant, so we can drop this feature if our model needs improvement.

Now we shall see if the subjects themselves have influence over each other

we can see that most of the students score above 40. the score are also linearly dependent on each other.
